details.title: Analysis of incomplete data in presence of competing risks among several groups

authors.affiliation: Dept. of Math. & Stat., Indian Inst. of Technol. Kanpur, India

p: Debasis Kundu is a Professor of Statistics in the Department of Mathematics and Statistics at the Indian Institute of Technology Kanpur. He received his B-Stat in 1982, and M.Stat in 1984 both from the Indian Statistical Institute, M.A (Mathematics) in 1985 from the University of Pittsburgh; and his Ph.D. in 1989 from the Pennsylvania State University. He has worked as a Tenure Track Assistant Professor in the University of Texas at Dallas from 1989 to 1990, and then joined Indian Institute of Technology Kanpur as an Assistant Professor in 1990. He became Professor in 1999. He is a Fellow of the National Academy of Sciences India. He is an Associate Editorof Communications of Statistics, Ser A and Ser B. His research interests include Statistical Signal Processing, Reliability Analysis, Statistical Computing, and Competing Risks Models.

authors.name: D. Kundu

authors.affiliation: Dept. of Math. & Stat., Indian Inst. of Technol. Kanpur, India

p: Ammar M. Sarhan received the B.S. (1985), and M.S. (1989) in Mathematics from Mathematics Dept., Faculty of Science, Mansoura University, Egypt; and the Ph.D (1996) in Mathematical Statistics from Institute of Mathematics, Gdansk University, Poland. Originally, he was working as an associated professor of Statistics in Mathematics Dept., Faculty of Science, Mansoura University, Egypt. But now, he is working as a professor of Statistics under a contract with Department of Statistics and Operation Research, College of Science, King Saud University, Saudi Arabia. His research interests include Reliability Analysis, Statistical Computing, Competing Risks Models, and Multivariate distributions.

authors.name: A.M. Sarhan

details.abstract: In reliability analysis, an investigator is often interested in the assessment of a specific risk in presence of other risk factors. It is well known as the competing risks problem in the statistical literature. In this paper, we consider the analysis of incomplete data in the presence of competing risks among several groups. We mainly consider the latent failure times model formulation, and it is assumed that the lifetime distributions of the different latent failure times of a particular group follow Weibull distributions with different scale parameters, but the same shape parameter. Maximum likelihood estimators of the different parameters are obtained using a simple iterative procedure, and also by EM algorithm. Asymptotic distributions of the maximum likelihood estimators of the different parameters are obtained, and based on the asymptotic distributions, asymptotic confidence intervals are also proposed. Testing equality of the parameters among several groups is performed. One data set has been analysed for illustrative purposes.

references.title:
Parametric inference of incomplete data with competing risks
among several groups

context.text: This work was motivated from the paper of Park & Kulasekera [1], and the data presented there, originally taken from Nelson [2].
Park & Kulasekera [1] analysed these data under the latent failure times model formulation, as suggested by Cox [3].
In this section, we analyze the data which was presented in Park & Kulasekera [1].
This work is mainly the continuation of the work of Park & Kulasekera [1].
Park & Kulasekera [1] analysed Nelson's [2] data assuming the lifetime distributions to be exponential for different groups.

links.abstract: We develop parametric inferential methods for the competing risks problem where data arise due to multiple causes of failure in several groups with censoring and possibly missing causes. We provide the general likelihood method and the closed-form maximum-likelihood estimators for the exponential model. Parametric tests are given for comparing different causes and groups. An extensive numerical and graphical investigation is presented to substantiate the proposed methods. A real-data example is ...

references.text: C. Park, K. B. Kulasekera, "Parametric inference of incomplete data with competing risks among several groups", IEEE Transactions on Reliability, vol. 53, pp. 11-21, 2004.
